history.content:
I cannot answer your first question, but I can speak to your second question.

The prerequisites are not enforced. Calcentral will still let you enroll in classes even if you have not taken any of the prerequisites. However, other students in the class will have met the prerequisites--this means that there is going to be a learning curve for you. So it might be beneficial to reach out to the professor lecturing, explain your background, and ask if you'd be a good fit for the course or if they have any resources for how you can prepare for it. Good luck! :)
On the first question, I believe your assumption is correct--I'm a non-major and I was able to directly enroll in an EE course and an EECS course in Phase I last semester.

Few questions about getting into EE courses without being an EECS/CS major:

  • I see on here that it says "In Phase I, any undergraduate student can enroll directly into these courses." To me it implies that me (a non EECS/CS major) can directly enroll into any EE course, i.e. not be put on the waitlist if there is space in the course at the time of my phase 1. Additionally, it implies that there are no restrictions placed on the number of seats assigned to EECS/CS majors, i.e. everyone has a fair chance of getting into the course as long as there is space. Are my assumptions correct?
  • I want to take a couple EE courses next semester, but they have prerequisites. How hard does the EE department enforce prereqs? Will I be able to enroll into any EE course without meeting the prereqs through CalCentral? For reference, the prereqs I don't meet are EE16A, EE16B, and EE120. When it says "consent of instructor" does that mean I have to get written consent from the instructor to take this course? How does this work?
history.subject: Getting into EE courses
